newsitem.title: UK: Rolls-Royce signs deal with Continental Airlines.
newsitem.headline: Rolls-Royce signs deal with Continental Airlines.

text.p: British engineering group Rolls-Royce Plc said on Tuesday it had won an order worth up to $240 million to supply engines to power up to 16 additional Continental Airlines Boeing 757 aircraft.
If all options are exercised, the deal would give U.S. airline Continental a Rolls-Royce powered 757 fleet of 41 aircraft.
Rolls-Royce Commercial Aero Engines managing director John Cheffins said the deal was important for two reasons.
"It expands our relationship with a valued customer and it adds Air Micronesia, a Continental affiliate, as yet another operator of the 535 engine," he said.
Share analysts said the deal confirmed Rolls-Royce's grip on the 757 engine market.
"It's quite a big deal and builds on their link with Continental. But they are the dominant force in 757s so it's no real surprise," said one.
Rolls-Royce shares were trading 3p lower at 225p at 0830 GMT on a London Stock Exchange which had suffered heavy losses on the back of Wall Street's fall.
Rolls-Royce said Continental had chosen its RB211-535 engine for the 757 passenger airliner because of its reliability and potential for cutting operating costs.
The deal also includes a repair and overhaul agreement between Continental and Rolls-Royce Canada which will provide the airline with an eight-year support package.
It also includes the purchase of over $45 million in spare engines from two Rolls-Royce units. That element is part of the potential $240 million overall value of the deal.
